heading: Welcome
text:
book contains solutions exercises course Statistics 1 
Economics Technische Universitaet Berlin winter term 2020/21.

heading: A Frequencies
Prerequisites
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(knitr)

# Set ggplot2 theme
theme_set(theme_bw())

heading: A.1 Exercise A1
A.1.1 Part A
text: duration study 200 industrial engineers examined. following results obtained:
code:
n <- 200
duration <- c(10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15)
rel_frequency <- c(0.1, 0.1, 0.4, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05)
tbl <- tibble(duration = duration, rel_frequency = rel_frequency) %>%
  mutate(cum_rel_frequency = cumsum(rel_frequency))

tbl## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##   duration rel_frequency cum_rel_frequency
##      <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>
## 1       10          0.1               0.1 
## 2       11          0.1               0.2 
## 3       12          0.4               0.6 
## 4       13          0.2               0.8 
## 5       14          0.15              0.95
## 6       15          0.05              1

heading: A.1.1.1 What is the statistical feature? How is it scaled?
text: feature duration study industrial engineer. interval-scaled.

heading: A.1.1.2 Determine the absolute frequencies.
code:
tbl <- mutate(tbl, abs_frequency = n * rel_frequency)
tbl$abs_frequency## [1] 20 20 80 40 30 10

heading: A.1.1.3 Determine the cumulative absolute frequencies.
code:
tbl <- mutate(tbl, cum_abs_frequency = cumsum(abs_frequency))
tbl$cum_abs_frequency## [1]  20  40 120 160 190 200

heading: A.1.1.4 Plot frequencies and cumulative (relative and absolute).
code:
# Relative frequencies
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_col(aes(x = duration, y = rel_frequency))
# Relative cumulative frequencies
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_point(aes(x = duration, y = cum_rel_frequency))
# Absolute frequencies
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_col(aes(x = duration, y = abs_frequency))
# Absolute cumulative frequencies
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_point(aes(x = duration, y = cum_abs_frequency))

heading: A.1.1.5 What is the maximum duration of study of the 10%-fastest students?
text: 10 semesters.

heading: A.1.1.6 What is the minimum duration of study of the 80%-slowest students?
text: 12 semesters.

heading: A.1.1.7 What is the duration of study for exact 20% of all students?
text: 13 semesters.

heading: A.1.2 Part B
text: Now consider feature \(Y\): duration study levels:small (less 12 semesters)medium (12 semesters)large (12 semesters)

heading: A.1.2.1 How is the feature Y scaled?
text: ordinal-scaled.

heading: A.1.2.2 Plot the absolute frequency function.
code:
# Function that converts duration to level
duration_to_level <- function(x) {
  if (x < 12) "small" else if (x == 12) "medium" else "large"
}
# Vectorize this function in order to work with vector input
duration_to_level <- Vectorize(duration_to_level)

# Prepare dataset
tbl <- select(tbl, duration, rel_frequency, abs_frequency) %>%
  mutate(level = duration_to_level(duration)) %>%
  group_by(level) %>%
  summarise(rel_frequency = sum(rel_frequency), abs_frequency = sum(abs_frequency))
tbl## # A tibble: 3 x 3
##   level  rel_frequency abs_frequency
##   <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl>
## 1 large            0.4            80
## 2 medium           0.4            80
## 3 small            0.2            40
# Plot
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_col(aes(x = level, y = abs_frequency))

heading: A.1.2.3 Does it make sense to use a cumulative distribution function for a nominal-scaled feature?
A.2 Exercise A2
text: 100m times 20 athletes measured. obtained following cumulative distribution function:

heading: A.2.1 Draw the corresponding histogram
code:
break_left <- c(10, 10.2, 10.6, 10.8)
break_right <- c(10.2, 10.6, 10.8, 11)
f <- c(0.1 / 0.2, 0.5 / 0.4, 0.2 / 0.2, 0.2 / 0.2)
tbl <- tibble(break_left = break_left, break_right = break_right, f = f)

ggplot(tbl, aes(xmin = break_left, xmax = break_right, ymax = f)) +
  geom_rect(ymin = 0) +
  labs(x = "x", y = "f(x)")

heading: A.2.2 Which was the maximum time of the 80%-fastest athletes?
text: 10.8 seconds.

heading: A.2.3 What is the assumption about the distribution of measured values within a group when determining the cumulative distribution function?
text: Uniform distribution within group.

heading: A.2.4 Use the cumulative distribution function to determine which was the maximum time needed by the five fastest athletes.
A.3 Exercise A3
text:
year tennis ace Boris B. participated 40 tournaments around world. Every tournament consisted six rounds:
* 1st Round
* 2nd Round
* 3rd Round (Round 16)
* 4th Round (Round 8)
* 5th Round (Semi-Final)
* 6th Round (Final)Boris satisfied overall performance. Even though reached final two times six times defeated semi-final, lost ten times 1st Round 16 times 2nd Round. never dropped 3rd Round.

heading: A.3.1 What is the statistical feature? How is it scaled?
text: feature number highest round Boris reached tournament. interval-scaled.

heading: A.3.2 Determine absolute and relative frequencies as well as absolute and relative cumulative frequencies.
code:
x <- 1:6
abs_frequency <- c(10, 16, 0, 6, 6, 2)
tbl <- tibble(x = x, abs_frequency = abs_frequency)

tbl <- tbl %>%
  mutate(rel_frequency = abs_frequency / sum(abs_frequency)) %>%
  mutate(cum_abs_frequency = cumsum(abs_frequency)) %>%
  mutate(cum_rel_frequency = cumsum(rel_frequency))
tbl## # A tibble: 6 x 5
##       x abs_frequency rel_frequency cum_abs_frequency cum_rel_frequency
##   <int>         <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>             <dbl>
## 1     1            10          0.25                10              0.25
## 2     2            16          0.4                 26              0.65
## 3     3             0          0                   26              0.65
## 4     4             6          0.15                32              0.8 
## 5     5             6          0.15                38              0.95
## 6     6             2          0.05                40              1

heading: A.3.3 Draw the empirical relative distribution function.
code:
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_col(aes(x = x, y = rel_frequency))

heading: A.3.4 At what percentage of tournaments Boris dropped out before the 3rd Round?
A.3.5 At what percentage of tournaments Boris reached at least the semi-finals?
A.3.6 At how many tournaments Boris played at least in the 2nd Round?
A.3.7 At most which round Boris dropped out in 80% of all tournaments?
text: 4th Round.

heading: A.3.8 Which round Boris dropped out in exact 40% of all tournaments?
text: 2nd Round.

heading: A.3.9 Give an interpretation of F(x) at x = 7.
text: \(F(7) = 1\), \(F(x) = 1 \, \forall \, x >= 6\). means impossible ever reach 7th Round exist.

heading: A.4 Exercise A4
text: 100 students asked much time spend studies per day. None spent 12 hours. 22 students spent six hours. 30% interviewed students spending less three hours, whereas 65% students invest three eight hours per day.

heading: A.4.1 What is the statistical feature? How is it scaled?
text: feature time student spends studies per day hours. ratio-scaled.

heading: A.4.2 Determine absolute, relative and cumulative frequencies. Group the data in four groups.
code:
n <- 100
break_left <- c(0, 3, 6, 8)
break_right <- c(3, 6, 8, 12)
# 22 students spent more than six hours -> 5 students spent more than 12 hours,
# 17 student spent between six and height hours
f <- c(0.3, 0.48, 0.17, 0.05)

tbl <- tibble(break_left = break_left, break_right = break_right, rel_frequency = f) %>%
  mutate(abs_frequency = rel_frequency * n) %>%
  mutate(cum_rel_frequency = cumsum(rel_frequency)) %>%
  mutate(cum_abs_frequency = cumsum(abs_frequency))

tbl## # A tibble: 4 x 6
##   break_left break_right rel_frequency abs_frequency cum_rel_frequen~
##        <dbl>       <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>
## 1          0           3          0.3             30             0.3 
## 2          3           6          0.48            48             0.78
## 3          6           8          0.17            17             0.95
## 4          8          12          0.05             5             1   
## # ... with 1 more variable: cum_abs_frequency <dbl>

heading: A.4.3 Visualize the absolute frequencies.
code:
ggplot(tbl) +
  geom_rect(
    aes(
      xmin = break_left, 
      xmax = break_right, 
      ymin = 0, 
      ymax = abs_frequency / (break_right - break_left)
    ),
    fill = "gray",
    color = "black"
  ) +
  labs(x = "x", y = "h(x)")

heading: A.4.4 Why did you choose this kind of visualization?
text: choose histogram meaningful visualization ratio-scaled data. Donâ€™t forget divide group width. area group proportionate absolute frequency height.

heading: A.4.5 Visualize the relative cumulative frequencies.
code:
x <- c(0, tbl$break_right)
cum_rel_frequency <- c(0, tbl$cum_rel_frequency)
tbl <- tibble(x = x, cum_rel_frequency = cum_rel_frequency)

ggplot(tbl, aes(x = x, y = cum_rel_frequency)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "x", y = "F(x)")

heading: A.4.6 Which assumption was made for your visualization?
text: distribution within group uniform.

heading: A.4.7 Use your visualization to find out how many hours at most spent 50% of all students?
A.4.8 How many students work more than five hours per day for their studies?

B Empirical Parameters
Prerequisites
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(knitr)

# Set ggplot2 theme
theme_set(theme_bw())

heading: Model Exercise B0 - Geometric mean
text: Statistix like invest savings 1,000 EUR project. project duration five years following annual interest rates:

heading: B.0.1 Show that the interest rate i_2 for time t_2 is exactly 12%.
B.0.2 Calculate the average interest rate per year based on the arithmetic mean.
B.0.3 Check your result by calculating the average interest rate over 5 years on the starting capital.
B.0.4 Now calculate the correct average annual interest rate.
B.0.5 Check your result.
B.1 Exercise B1
text: Mister Maier owns garden gnome wholesale three stores Berlin, New York Flensburg. end business year, wants overview business situation therefore requests information three stores orders received within last year.

heading: B.1.1 Part A
text: Berlin store providing following data:
code:
# Prerequisites
break_left <- c(0, 20, 50, 150)
break_right <- c(20, 50, 150, 300)
n_orders <- c(15, 30, 45, 10)
n_berlin <- sum(n_orders)

tbl <- tibble(break_left = break_left, break_right = break_right, n_orders = n_orders)

kable(tbl)

heading: B.1.1.1 Determine relative cumulative frequencies.
code:
tbl <- tbl %>%
  mutate(rel_frequency = n_orders / 100) %>%
  mutate(cum_rel_frequency = cumsum(rel_frequency)) %>%
  print()## # A tibble: 4 x 5
##   break_left break_right n_orders rel_frequency cum_rel_frequency
##        <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>
## 1          0          20       15          0.15             0.15 
## 2         20          50       30          0.3              0.450
## 3         50         150       45          0.45             0.9  
## 4        150         300       10          0.1              1

heading: B.1.1.2 Determine lower and upper quartile and median. Draw a box plot.
B.1.1.3 Calculate the mean order value.
code:
tbl <- tbl %>%
  mutate(group_mean = (break_left + break_right) / 2) %>%
  print() %>%
  mutate(total_order_value = group_mean * n_orders) %>%
  print() %>%
  summarise(mean_order_value = sum(total_order_value) / sum(n_orders)) %>%
  print()## # A tibble: 4 x 6
##   break_left break_right n_orders rel_frequency cum_rel_frequency group_mean
##        <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>             <dbl>      <dbl>
## 1          0          20       15          0.15             0.15          10
## 2         20          50       30          0.3              0.450         35
## 3         50         150       45          0.45             0.9          100
## 4        150         300       10          0.1              1            225
## # A tibble: 4 x 7
##   break_left break_right n_orders rel_frequency cum_rel_frequen~ group_mean
##        <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>      <dbl>
## 1          0          20       15          0.15            0.15          10
## 2         20          50       30          0.3             0.450         35
## 3         50         150       45          0.45            0.9          100
## 4        150         300       10          0.1             1            225
## # ... with 1 more variable: total_order_value <dbl>
## # A tibble: 1 x 1
##   mean_order_value
##              <dbl>
## 1             79.5
x_bar_berlin <- tbl$mean_order_value

heading: B.1.1.4 What is your assumptions for this calculation?
text: Uniform distribution within group.

heading: B.1.1.5 What is the biggest possible difference between the mean of the original data and the mean of the grouped data
text: Half group width, means 75.000 EUR.

heading: B.1.2 Part B
text: story New York answers request follows:\[95 \, \mathrm{orders} \, | \, \bar{x} = 60.000\$ \, | \, s^2 = 16.000.000\$^2\]improve comparability, Mister Maier wants get information EUR.

heading: Prerequisites
code: n_new_york <- 95

heading: B.1.2.1 Calculate the corresponding values for an exchange rate of 1$ = 1.5 EUR.
code:
x_bar_dollar <- 60000
x_bar_new_york <- 60000 * 1.5

var_dollar <- 16e6
# 1st variant
sd_dollar <- sqrt(var_dollar)
sd_euro <- sd_dollar * 1.5
var_new_york <- sd_euro^2
# 2nd variant
var_new_york_2 <- var_dollar * 1.5^2

x_bar_new_york## [1] 90000
var_new_york## [1] 3.6e+07
var_new_york_2## [1] 3.6e+07

heading: B.1.3 Part C
text: Flensburg Mister Maier gets following data:
code:
x_flensburg <- c(2e3, 12e3, 17e3, 12e3, 200e3)
n_flensburg <- length(x_flensburg)

heading: B.1.3.1 Calculation of which means is meaningful in this case?
text: telex corrects value last order 2 000 instead 200 000.
code:
# Arithmetic mean
mean(x_flensburg)## [1] 48600
# Geometric mean
prod(x_flensburg)^(1 / length(x_flensburg))## [1] 15782.44

heading: B.1.3.2 Based on the corrected data calculate arithmetic mean and standard deviation of order values.
code:
x_flensburg[length(x_flensburg)] <- 2000

x_bar_flensburg <- mean(x_flensburg)
x_bar_flensburg## [1] 9000
# IMPORTANT: Don't use sd as it computes the sample 
# standard deviation instead of the empirical 
# standard deviation
sd_flensburg <- sqrt(1 / n_flensburg * sum((x_flensburg - x_bar_flensburg)^2))
var_flensburg <- sd_flensburg^2

heading: B.1.3.3 Compare the deviation of order value between the New York and the Flensburg store using an appropriate measure.
code:
# New York (compare Part B)
var_new_york## [1] 3.6e+07
# Flensburg
var_flensburg## [1] 3.6e+07
# New York and Flensburg stores share the same standard deviation 
# and variance.

heading: B.1.3.4 Calculate the mean order value for the whole business
code:
# Berlin (compare Part A)
total_order_value_berlin <- 100 * 79.5e3

# New York (compare Part B)
total_order_value_new_york <- 95 * 90e3

# Flensburg
total_order_value_flensburg <- sum(x_flensburg)

mean_order_value <- (
  total_order_value_berlin + total_order_value_new_york + total_order_value_flensburg
) / (100 + 95 + 5)
mean_order_value## [1] 82725

heading: B.1.3.5 Calculate the empirical variance of order value for the whole business.
code:
# Berlin variance
n_orders <- c(15, 30, 45, 10)
x_bar_berlin_groups <- c(10e3, 35e3, 100e3, 225e3)
var_berlin <- 1 / n_berlin * sum(n_orders * (x_bar_berlin_groups - x_bar_berlin)^2)
var_berlin## [1] 9932365820
# Values from previous tasks
n_cities <- c(n_berlin, n_new_york, n_flensburg)
x_bar_cities <- c(x_bar_berlin, x_bar_new_york, x_bar_flensburg)
var_cities <- c(var_berlin, var_new_york, var_flensburg)

# Total variance
var_all <- 1 / sum(n_cities) * (
  sum(n_cities * var_cities) + sum(n_cities * (x_bar_cities - mean(x_bar_cities))^2)
)

heading: B.1.3.6 Which percentage of total variance is generated by considering each store separately?
code: 1 / sum(n_cities) * sum(n_cities * (x_bar_cities - mean(x_bar_cities))^2) / var_all## [1] 0.2963381

text: Multiple Choice QuestionsOne speaks principle equal area , graphic representation absolute frequencies grouped data, flatness block proportional absolute frequency represented.True.frequency distributions two cardinally scaled features identical even two features arithmetic mean variance.True.Statistical quantities can classified respect value range.True.empirical distribution function defined values also observed.False? Empirical means observed. One argue use aggregated values instead bare observations.empirical quartile distance ordered data set measure variability outlier-sensitive.False.step heights empirical (relative) distribution function correspond relative cumulative frequencies.False, correspond relative frequencies.coefficient variation dimensionless measure.True.: \(h(a_j) = n\) , underlying statistical characteristic one possibility realization.False. possible realizations just observed, may surely exist.train travels \(97 \, \mathrm{km}\) speed \(64 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}\) another \(97 \, \mathrm{km}\) speed \(192 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}\) . average speed total distance 96km/h.True. \(\frac{97 \, \mathrm{km} + 97 \, \mathrm{km}}{\frac{1}{64} \frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{km}} \cdot 97 \, \mathrm{km} + \frac{1}{192} \frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{km}} \cdot 97 \, \mathrm{km}} = 96 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}\).statistical characteristic called continuous range values countably infinite.False. range must uncountably infinite.

Prerequisites

library(ggplot2)

heading: D.1 Exercise D1
text: survey, 200 father-son pairs asked voting behavior last election. Create contingency table using following information:sons chose parties \(\), \(B\) \(C\) ratio \(2:1:2\).Half fathers voted Party \(B\) must face fact sons prefer Party \(\).5% sons interviewed - like fathers - chose party .Party B won 40% votes.15% fathers gave vote Party C.20 sons whose fathers voted Party chose Party B.30 fathers voted party sons.

heading: D.2 Exercise D2
text: context developing marketing strategy latest product, marketing department company conducted survey hope obtaining information promising packaging color. purpose, total 600 units product offered three different test markets. Several employees far collected following information pieces sold test markets:number units sold test market line packaging color (black, red, white) ratio 1:3:1.30% pieces sold Test Market II packed black.25% offered pieces sold.many black-packaged pieces sold white-packaged pieces.175 pieces sold Test Market III.number pieces sold Test Market II represented 75% total number red wrapped pieces sold Test Markets.Test Market , 50 fewer pieces sold Test Market III.35% red wrapped pieces sold sold Test Market III.

heading: D.2.1 Present the data obtained from the examination in tabular form in a contingency table.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.1 Be \(A\), \(B\), \(C\) \(\subset \omega\) events. The event: â€œAt least two of these events occurâ€ can be represented graphically as follows:

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.2 From \(n\) objects \(r\) elements shall be selected. Then the number of choices for a variation with repetition can not be smaller than for a variation without repetition.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.3 The certain event has the probability one. But an event with a probability of one is only â€œalmost certainâ€.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.4 Two events, which have no common elements, are disjoint.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.5 Using the objective concept of probability, the individual case is considered, but not the series (â€œlong runâ€).

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.6 For two events \(A\) and \(B\) applies: \(P(A \cap B) \le P(A) \le P(A \cup B) \le P(A) + P(B)\).

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.7 If three events \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) are stochastically independent in pairs, then there is valid: \(P(A \cap B \cap C) = P(A) \cdot P(B) \cdot P(C)\).

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.8 If three events \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) are completely disjoint [i.e.Â \((A \cap B \cap C) = \emptyset\)], then they are also disjoint in pairs [i.e.Â \((A \cap B) = \emptyset\), \((B \cap C) = \emptyset\) and \((C \cap A) = \emptyset\)].

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.9 Let \(A\) and \(B\) be events (with: \(0 < P(A) < 1\) and \(0 < P(B) < 1\)). If \(P(A \cap B) = 0\), then \(A\) and \(B\) are stochastically independent.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.3.1.10 The probability of throwing a non-ideal die twice with a maximum of a â€œ6â€ is equal to the probability of not throwing a â€œ6â€ at least once.

heading: F.13.2.6 Are the events \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) completely stochastically independent? [i.e.Â \(P(A \cap B \cap C) = P(A) \cdot P(B) \cdot P(C)\)]

heading: F.14.1 Part A
text: family picnic today: Father Martin, mother Silke, children Anja Dirk well grandpa Arnold. way home children suddenly notice grandpa longer . three possibilities:\(\): Grandpa already home sitting comfortably armchair.\(B\): Grandpa still picnic area taking nap.\(C\): Grandpa gone nearby forest looking mushrooms.habits grandpa, one knows probabilities occurrence events \(\), \(B\) \(C\):\[P() = 0.15, \, P(B) = 0.8, \, P(C) = 0.05 \, .\]Anja sent back picnic place Dirk sent edge forest look grandfather. grandpa picnic place, Anja finds probability 90%. running around forest, Dirk find probability 50%.

text: florist assortment tulip bulbs. bulbs 20% make blue tulips, rest make red tulips. 60% bulbs make tulips smooth leaves, rest make tulips pointed leaves. tulip blue, smooth leaves 10% cases.applies:R: â€œThe tulip turns red.â€G: â€œThe tulip smooth leaves.â€

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.15.1.1 Calculate the probability that a tulip will have red color and smooth leaves.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.15.1.2 Calculate the probability that a tulip will turn red if you know that it will have smooth leaves.

chapter: F Combinatorics and Algebra of Events
heading: F.15.1.3 Calculate the probability that a tulip will have smooth leaves if you know that it will turn red.
